bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, February 26, 1942

div1.p: Hench inquires about the anticipated Cuban unveiling of the Cornwell paintings, which he would like to attend if possible. He informs Kellogg that Hoffmann is a member of the Finlay Institute.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, February 26, 1942
div1.opener:
Y F
February 26, 1942
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
It will be months before I will get my yellow fever thing ready. I
am still in the process of searching for material, some of which I know exists
and some of which I don't even know exists yet which I am looking for in official
and unofficial journals. As you say, the current interest in yellow fever will
increase interest in the whole story greatly. Dr. Sawyer of the Rockefeller
Institute is responsible for the vaccine--a really excellent thing and the only
real contribution to the conquest of yellow fever since the work of the yellow
fever board in 1900. Dr. Sawyer was a fellow speaker with me at the Washington
and Jefferson affair last year.

By the way, can you give me any more dope on the anticipated Cuban
meeting and the unveiling of the paintings, including the Cuban versions? I
imagine if you go you would like to borrow from me the Cuban versions. I am
really anxious to know. Already twenty of our permanent staff have left and
about seventy of our Fellows have gone for military duty. We anticipate losing
twenty-five more of our permanent staff within the next few months so that if
I go, unless I can save part of my month's vacation for the Cuban trip in the
Fall, I suspect the Clinic would not want me to go. If you are still planning
seriously on holding the Cuban meeting, I will materially shorten my vacation to
California at the end of April. If not, I will take my whole vacation at one
time. You will see, therefore, why I am anxious to know. I realize that you
yourself will not know but if you think there is a fairly good chance of holding
it I will try to shorten my California vacation in April.

As to the matter of Dr. Hoffman, thanks for sending me the copy of
his letter to you. In rereading his letter I don't know whether he wants two
hundred copies of my reprints or simply two hundred copies of the painting. It
looks as if he wants the latter and apparently from his letter to you, you have
reserved that number for him. Do you know what he wants? If you have reserved
that many for him there is no use in my sending him two hundred of my reprints.
I have just had a letter from Dr. Albertini, who says that Dr. Hoffman is a member
of the Finlay Institute where he is histologist and has been for long years inter-
ested in yellow fever. He does not say much about him but what he does say seems
to be all right. I won't write Hoffman until I hear from you. There is no use
in sending him the whole Hygeia reprint if all he wants is the colored insert.
Please let me know.

Can you send me a few more colored reproductions of the two Cuban ver-
sions? Please don't go to any bother, certainly not to any expense to have this
done but if you have some lying around, I would like a half dozen more.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
